---
title: "R Stuff"
---

The R learning curve was tough for me, but worth it. Here are some resources that I found invaluable in learning R to facilitate my data science, stats, and open science practices, and most of these continue to be go-to resources.

# Free Resources

[R for Data Science (Hadley Wickham)](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/)

[SEM Intro (Michael Hallquist)](https://psu-psychology.github.io/r-bootcamp-2018/talks/lavaan_tutorial.html)

[Easystats Ecoystem](https://github.com/easystats/easystats)

[Multilevel Modeling using rstanarm](https://mc-stan.org/users/documentation/case-studies/tutorial_rstanarm.html)

[Hayes PROCESS code](https://afhayes.com/mediation-and-moderation-analysis-workshops.html)

[Best Practices for Writing R Code](https://swcarpentry.github.io/r-novice-inflammation/06-best-practices-R/index.html)

[Google Developers Videos for Learning R](https://www.r-bloggers.com/2013/08/google-developers-r-programming-video-lectures-2/)

## Basic R Intro e-books

[Venables et al](https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-intro.pdf)

[Douglas et al.](https://intro2r.com/)

## Multivariate Stats in R e-books

[Zelterman (warning, opens to large PDF)](https://web.uniroma1.it/memotef/sites/default/files/file%20lezioni/102b_textbook.pdf)

[Everitt (usually free if you have academic access)](https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9781852338824)

# Not Free Resources

[Fox and Weisberg](https://www.amazon.com/R-Companion-Applied-Regression/dp/1544336470/ref=sr_1_3?crid=14O8CE1LEJB8M&dchild=1&keywords=john+fox+regression&qid=1622819129&sprefix=john+fox+r%2Caps%2C207&sr=8-3) (this is the companion for the well known `car` library)
